item.title: Iran Says Supreme Leader Killed in U.S.-Israeli Strikes
item.description: The death of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei raised questions about leadership succession as attacks on Iran, and its responses, continued.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times

item.title: The Bloody Rise and Fall of Mexico’s Top Crime Boss
item.description: El Mencho’s brutality and business acumen put him atop the cartel world, until he made a fatal mistake.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Paulina Villegas and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: After Mexican forces killed a notorious cartel kingpin on Sunday, his followers set fire to hundreds of vehicles, like this one beside a highway in Jalisco state.

item.title: Trump Gives Green Light to Private Oil Sales to Cuba
item.description: After blocking foreign oil shipments, the Trump administration is now allowing small amounts of oil to enter Cuba — as long as they circumvent government hands.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:description: The Nico Lopez oil refinery in Havana this month.

item.title: Carney Visiting India, Australia and Japan to Build Canada’s ‘Middle Power’ Bonds
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney visits India, Australia and Japan seeking deals to strengthen his country’s links to Indo-Pacific powers and break Canada’s dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, with his wife, Diana Fox Carney, arriving in Mumbai, India, on Friday.

item.title: Taiwan Arms Sale Approved by Congress Is Delayed as Trump Plans Visit to Beijing
item.description: The package worth billions of dollars and endorsed by lawmakers is stalled at the State Department as the U.S. and China plan an April summit.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Robert Jimison
item.media:description: An Air Force Patriot missile system was deployed at a local park during Taiwan’s annual Han Kuang military exercise last year.

item.title: Pakistan Strikes Afghanistan in ‘Open War’ Against Taliban Regime
item.description: The airstrikes came hours after Afghan troops had attacked Pakistani border positions and follow months of worsening relations between the neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Safiullah Padshah and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Taliban soldiers looking toward Pakistan from the Afghan side of the Torkham border crossing, on Friday.

item.title: A Trump Call Ignited Saudi-U.A.E. Feud
item.description: A request made to President Trump about the war in Sudan is at the heart of a diplomatic dispute between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia at an investment forum in Washington in November.

item.title: Some Russians Go Without Heat or Power in Winter, as Energy System Falls Into Disrepair
item.description: A dozen major blackouts and central heating cutoffs across the country have affected hundreds of thousands during a brutal winter.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Murmansk, Russia, in 2023. The city has been plagued by power and heating outages this winter.

item.title: Were Duterte’s Speeches Orders to Kill or Hyperbole?
item.description: Judges at the International Criminal Court have heard starkly different interpretations this week of the words of former President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Aie Balagtas See
item.media:description: Outside the International Criminal Court this week. Hearings have drawn critics and supporters of Rodrigo Duterte, who as president of the Philippines ordered a brutal crackdown on drugs.

item.title: Hungary Plays Spoiler in Europe as Orban Strains for Votes at Home
item.description: Facing a serious election challenge, Prime Minister Viktor Orban is holding up a big E.U. loan for Ukraine. Analysts say the timing is no coincidence.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary in Budapest last month.

item.title: Israel Facing Prospect of War With a Depleted Missile Defense
item.description: The June 2025 conflict with Iran depleted Israeli and U.S. stocks of antiballistic missiles. If there is another war, the pressure will be on to destroy Iranian missiles before they can be launched.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Israeli air defense systems were activated to intercept Iranian missiles over the Israeli city of Tel Aviv in June.

item.title: Green Party Defeats Labour in U.K. Special Election, in Blow to Starmer
item.description: The result marks the first time the Greens have won a British parliamentary by-election and signals the frustration of left-leaning voters with Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Stephen Castle and Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Ms. Spencer outside a polling station in the Gorton and Denton district near Manchester, England.

item.title: Amid Rhetoric About Rupture With U.S., Finland Urges Calm
item.description: “We don’t need a bulldozer,” says Alexander Stubb, Finland’s president and a golf partner of President Trump. “Reform doesn’t mean destruction.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Saara Mansikkamaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Alexander Stubb of Finland, last year. Mr. Stubb says he recognizes that the world has changed, perhaps forever, and that Europe is not Washington’s priority.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.description: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aliko Dangote at home in Lagos, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: In Ukraine, a Community of ‘Simple Believers’ Shuns the Modern World
item.description: The Christians known as viruiuchi prostaky see electricity, cars, higher education and much else as distractions from what really matters.
item.dc:creator: Mauricio Lima and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:description: Laying a foundation for a house in the village of Kosmyryn, in western Ukraine, in November.

item.title: Iranians Take to Streets to Celebrate Khamenei’s Death
item.description: Some Iranians said on social media that they were privately mourning the supreme leader. But displays of exuberance broke out in cities across the country.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Hard-Line Cleric Who Made Iran a Regional Power, Is Dead at 86
item.description: As Iran’s second supreme leader, he brutally crushed dissent at home and expanded Iran’s footprint abroad, challenging Saudi Arabia for regional dominance.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who ruled for more than three decades, shaped Iran’s Islamic revolution far more than the Islamic Republic’s founder, Ayatollah Khomeini.

item.title: After Iran Attacks, Ship Traffic Plummets in Strait of Hormuz
item.description: One of the world’s most vital maritime arteries saw a 70 percent drop in vessel traffic.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Alexander Cardia
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)

item.title: Who Could Take Over for Ayatollah Ali Khamenei?
item.description: Now that Iran has declared that its supreme leader is dead, it is unclear which of his possible successors might rise.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times, Ebrahim Noroozi/Associated Press

item.title: False and outdated videos circulated online after the Iran strikes.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: See a Breakdown of Ayatollah Khamenei and Other Top Iranian Leaders
item.description: Among those killed in strikes, according to the U.S. and Israel, were Iran’s supreme leader and three of his top military commanders.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Granados
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)

item.title: The attacks touched off protests across the United States and abroad.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn, Zia Haider Rahman and Robert Chiarito
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in Times Square in New York on Saturday was one of dozens of protests across the country and around the world opposing the joint U.S.-Israel strikes on Iran.

item.title: Middle East Airspace Closes as U.S.-Israeli Strikes Hit Iran
item.description: A major hub in Dubai has suspended operations following U.S.-Israeli strikes on Iran. The sweeping closures are stranding passengers.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: The check-in desk for Emirates airline at London Gatwick Airport on Saturday. The airline announced that all operations to and from Dubai had been paused.

item.title: Israel Targeted Top Iranian Leaders in Attack’s Opening Strikes
item.description: At least one gathering of senior officials and military leaders was hit, but it was not immediately clear whether the effort to kill them had succeeded.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Aaron Boxerman
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)

item.title: Mapping the U.S.-Led Attacks on Iran
item.description: Maps show where U.S. and Israel have struck Iran, and where Iran has retaliated.
item.dc:creator: Lazaro Gamio, Samuel Granados, Josh Holder, Blacki Migliozzi, Pablo Robles, Helmuth Rosales, Elena Shao and Daniel Wood
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)

item.title: The Trump administration notified Congress in advance of the Iran strikes.
item.description: The notification stood in contrast to past military actions President Trump has undertaken unilaterally without consulting with Congress, drawing bipartisan anger.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison, Michael Gold, Julian Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lack of transparency on military operations that has characterized President Trump’s second term so far has fueled bipartisan frustration in Congress.

item.title: No Clear Endgame in the Conflict Between Afghanistan and Pakistan
item.description: Pakistan’s airstrikes in Afghanistan showed its overwhelming superiority in conventional warfare, but the Taliban have refined a lethal repertoire of guerrilla tactics.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Pakistani airstrikes threatened to inflict major damage on cities in Afghanistan, which was already reeling from economic hardship and a humanitarian crisis.

item.title: Trump’s Unilateral Iran Strike Sparks Constitutional War Powers Dispute
item.description: Critics say the president is violating the Constitution, and many Democrats and at least two Republicans in Congress say they must vote on whether to enter such a conflict.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump himself described the attack as “major combat operations” that could result in American casualties.

item.title: Iran Says Dozens Are Killed in Strike on School
item.description: The strike on an elementary school in the southern Iran town of Minab was one of two attacks that appear to have hit schools during U.S. and Israeli strikes on Iran on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Malachy Browne and Haley Willis

item.title: Netanyahu Takes His Shot at Regime Change in Iran
item.description: The United States and Israel have declared their war aim as paving the way for a popular uprising against the government in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, where he met with President Donald Trump in December.

item.title: Iranian Attacks on Israel Shine a Light on Shelter Shortage
item.description: The missile barrages highlight a shortage of bomb shelters in a country that has been preparing for war with Iran for decades.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: People made their way into a public bomb shelter in the center of Tel Aviv as early warning alerts of missile launches from Iran were sent on Saturday.

item.title: Members of U.S. Congress Are Divided on U.S. Strikes in Iran
item.description: As explosions rocked Tehran, Republicans largely voiced support as Democrats warned about a costly and unauthorized conflict.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: See photos and videos from the Middle East after the U.S.-led attacks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Iran Hits Back Across the Mideast, Targeting U.S. Bases and Allies
item.description: Waves of retaliatory strikes were reported in Israel and across several Gulf countries on Saturday. The Emirati government said at least one person was killed from falling missile debris.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Smoke rises in the sky after a blast in Manama, Bahrain, on Saturday.

item.title: Several rounds of U.S.-Iran nuclear talks failed to stave off strikes.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Erika Solomon and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Beirut, Lebanon, in January. He had said that the most recent round of negotiations ended with an agreement on a “set of guiding principles.”

item.title: After Attack on Iran by the U.S. and Israel, See Photos and Videos From the Middle East
item.description: See images from the Middle East after the United States and Israel on Saturday launched a major attack against Tehran.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People stood on rooftops in Tehran on Saturday as rumors of the death of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, spread.

item.title: As U.S. Bombs Tehran, Some Iranians Feel Abandoned by Their Leaders
item.description: The government provided little advice in the days before the attacks or as the bombs fell, more than a dozen Iranians said in interviews.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Tehran on Saturday. In telephone and text interviews in the hours after the attacks, many Iranians said they had been left to fend for themselves.

item.title: Israelis Take Shelter as Sirens Warn of Incoming Missiles
item.description: People across the country took cover from Iran’s retaliatory strikes. “Oh, I did not miss this sound,” one woman said of the air raid alerts.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed, Gabby Sobelman and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered in a bomb shelter in Tel Aviv on Saturday following an air raid warning.

item.title: Trump’s case for striking Iran rests on questionable claims.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A large Iranian flag is carried during a march to commemorate the 47th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution in Tehran, in February.

item.title: Leaders of E.U., Canada and Other Countries React to U.S.-led Attack on Iran
item.description: Governments around the world urged restraint after the United States and Israel launched a major assault, and Iran vowed retaliation.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A plume of smoke rises after an explosion in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: What to Know About the U.S. Attacks on Iran
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, was killed in the major assault launched by the United States and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Shawna Richer
item.category: US and Israeli Attack on Iran (2026)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Plumes of smoke rose after a reported explosion in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: How The Times Covers Cartels and Other Criminal Enterprises
item.description: Cultivating sources. Verifying claims. Staying safe. After the death of El Mencho, four journalists share their approach to this difficult, dangerous work.
item.dc:creator: Megan DiTrolio, Paulina Villegas, Jack Nicas, Maria Abi-Habib and Lauren Katzenberg
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remnants of retaliatory violence, including burned vehicles, was evident along the highway between Guadalajara and Tapalpa, in Jalisco state.

item.title: U.S. Has Annexed Canada in Toronto Artist’s Speculative Series
item.description: A speculative public art series that began in alleyways and on buildings and a tennis court fence is opening as a chilling new show at Western University.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The artist Dara Vandor with a plaque from her project “Pax Americana” at the Weldon Library on the campus of Western University.

item.title: Initial Focus of U.S. Strikes in Iran Is Military Targets
item.description: Dozens of attacks were carried out by warplanes launched from bases and aircraft carriers in the region. President Trump said the targets included missile sites, Iran’s navy and nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A handout photo made available by the Iranian Army Office in 2025 shows a projectile being launched during a military drill at an undisclosed location in Iran.

item.title: Chaos and Panic Grip Tehran as Airstrikes Shake City
item.description: Iranians were beginning their workweek as U.S. and Israeli strikes sent people fleeing parts of the capital and parents racing to collect children from schools.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman stood on a rooftop to get a view of explosions in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Calls for Overthrow of Iran’s Government
item.description: In an eight-minute video, President Trump announced a “massive” campaign of U.S. strikes on Iran and urged the Iranian people to rise up once they end.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: An attack on Iran carries risks for the U.S., experts say.
item.description: Iran’s medium‑range ballistic missiles are capable of traveling more than 1,200 miles, putting them in range of several American bases.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Samuel Granados

item.title: The U.S. last bombed Iran in June, striking three nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: This satellite image shows damage at the Fordo enrichment facility in Iran after U.S. strikes in June.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Trump ‘Not Happy’ With Iran Talks, but Says He Remains Undecided on Strikes
item.description: President Trump said he had not made a final decision about whether to order military action against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump addressing reporters before leaving the White House for a trip to Texas on Friday.

item.title: Iran’s Students Are Protesting Again. Here’s Why.
item.description: The unrest underlines the intensity of domestic discontent, even as Tehran’s government grapples with the threat of U.S. strikes. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: An image taken from social media on Monday shows students gathering for an anti-government rally at the women-only Al Zahra University in Tehran.

item.title: Mapping the Risks of Attacking Iran
item.description: Our national security correspondent David E. Sanger maps Iran’s options for retaliation if the United States or Israel strikes.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Coleman Lowndes, Abdi Latif Dahir, Samuel Granados, Stephanie Swart, Lazaro Gamio and Ray Whitehouse

item.title: Why Are Pakistan and Afghanistan Fighting?
item.description: The renewed violence between the neighboring countries stems from Pakistan’s accusations that Afghanistan’s Taliban government has harbored a militant group.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Lynsey Chutel and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Taliban security personnel handling an antiaircraft gun in Afghanistan’s Khost Province on Friday.

item.title: Fighting Wildfires Could Soon Get Harder
item.description: Simultaneous emergencies in different parts of the world could stop countries from sharing ground crews and equipment, new research warns.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak
item.media:description: A wildfire this month in Chubut Province, Argentina. Different parts of the world have historically had different fire seasons, allowing regions to rotate resources.

item.title: With Possible Iran Strike Looming, U.S. Says Staff Can Leave Israel, and Urges Speed
item.description: In an email to embassy workers Friday morning, Ambassador Mike Huckabee warned them that if they wanted to leave Israel, they “should do so TODAY.”
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: U.S. Ambassador to Israel Mike Huckabee at his office in the embassy in Jerusalem, in August.

item.title: South Korea Clears Way for Google Maps to Fully Operate
item.description: South Korea approved Google’s request to export detailed map data, reversing a longstanding restriction that made the tool largely nonfunctional.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Unlike in most countries, Google Maps has not provided real-time driving or walking directions in South Korea.

item.title: Trump’s Foreign Policy: Resurrecting Empire
item.description: President Trump’s approach is a revival of the mission of empire — acquiring the territories and resources of sovereign peoples.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, right, has been leading the Trump administration’s foreign policy.

item.title: Iranians Cite Progress in Talks, but a Marathon Session Produces No Deal
item.description: Representatives of the countries were in Geneva this week to discuss the fate of Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff, who, with Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, is negotiating with Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi.
